content.rendered:
New for 2025: Video for 1980; audio for 2006; new entry for 2024

1954: Future Seeger Sessions Band member and E Streeter Charlie Giordano is born in Brooklyn.

1973: At the last minute, Columbia Records cancels a promotional preview show for The Wild, The Innocent & The E Street Shuffle at the Kennedy Center in Washington, DC. No reason is provided.

1976: Bruce and the E Street Band bring the Lawsuit Tour to Kean College in Union, New Jersey.

1977: Bruce joins Southside Johnny on stage for four songs (including “Down in the Valley” and “Ain’t Too Proud to Beg“) at The Stone Pony in Asbury Park.

1980: Bruce releases his fifth studio album, The River, and The River Tour (already in progress) moves on to the St Paul Civic Center Arena for one night. Parts of the show are captured on Super-8 film.

1986: Neil and Pegi Young hold their first benefit for The Bridge School for children with special needs in Mountain View, California, and Neil enlists a few friends for the inaugural event. Former bandmate Nils Lofgren plays a set (in which Bruce makes a brief guest appearance), and Bruce plays a rare (at the time, at least) acoustic set with Nils and Danny as well. Of note: a new arrangement for “Seeds” set to the tune of “Rockaway the Days,” and an a capella “You Can Look (But You Better Not Touch).” Crosby, Stills, Nash & Young join Bruce for “Hungry Heart,” and Tom Petty, Don Henley, and Robin Williams join Bruce and CSNY for the “Teach Your Children” finale. This show is available as part of Bruce’s official archive series–get it here.

1992: After an unplanned week off due to illness, Bruce picks World Tour 1992 back up at the Tacoma Dome.

2004: Bruce and Jackson Browne hold an encore concert for the Vote for Change Tour at the Continental Airlines Arena in East Rutherford. Patti opens the event, with Bruce joining her for two numbers; Jackson follows, with a Bruce guest-appearance on “Running on Empty.” Bruce’s set features guest appearances not only by Jackson Browne (on “Racing in the Street“) but notably Eddie Vedder for three numbers featuring Bruce’s live debut of “Better Man” complete with an inspired sax solo by Clarence.

2005: Bruce brings his solo acoustic Devils & Dust Tour to Chicago’s United Center.

2006: The Seeger Sessions Tour stops in Rotterdam for a show at Sportpaleis Ahoy.

2007: Bruce joins the Max Weinberg 7 for six songs during their benefit performance for the Monmouth County SPCA at Max’s farm in Atlantic Highlands, New Jersey.

2009: Bruce and the E Street Band kick off one final stand of four shows at the Philadelphia Spectrum before its scheduled demolition. Each show will be special in its own right, starting from the first number of the first show: the tour premiere and first E Street Band performance of “Seaside Bar Song” in 36 years. This show also features a full album performance of Born to Run, Bruce’s only performance of “Little Bit O’Soul” to date, and a rare outing for “The Fever.”

2017: Bruce settles in for a long run of Springsteen on Broadway at the Walter Kerr Theater in New York City. This is Night Two.

2018: It’s Night Two Hundred for Springsteen on Broadway at the Walter Kerr Theater in New York City. In attendance to help celebrate: comedian Chris Rock, actor Laurence Fishburne, and author Nelson George.

2019: Bruce spends the weekend at the Ham Yard Hotel in London. speaking to print and broadcast journalists about his Western Stars film, most of which will be printed and aired over the weeks to come.

2021: Without fanfare, Bruce concludes his long-running From My Home to Yours radio show with Episode 29, “Let’s Talk About Sex.”

2024: Bruce performs “The Ghost of Tom Joad” and “Dancing in the Dark” at a benefit gala for the USC Shoah Foundation in New York City.

View this post on Instagram

A post shared by Kevin Mazur (@kevinmazur)

excerpt.rendered: Happy birthday, Charlie Giordano and The River! Also on this date: Bruce plays an acoustic set at the first Bridge School Benefit, an epic E Street Band performance of “Better Man” with Bruce and Eddie Vedder, and much more.

jetpack-related-posts.title: Kingdom of Days: May 16
jetpack-related-posts.author: Ken
jetpack-related-posts.excerpt: On this date: a mini-Seeger Sessions reunion, an Edwin Starr guest appearance, the release of "We've Got the Love," and more.

jetpack-related-posts.title: Kingdom of Days: May 5
jetpack-related-posts.author: Ken
jetpack-related-posts.excerpt: On this date: Bruce receives Sweden's Polar Music Prize. Watch full footage plus more highlights inside.

jetpack-related-posts.title: Kingdom of Days: May 20
jetpack-related-posts.author: Ken
jetpack-related-posts.excerpt: Watch Bruce and his new band rehearse for their 1992 tour, and then listen to Joe Ely and Jerry Lee Lewis join them on stage a year later. These and more highlights from this date inside.

jetpack-related-posts.title: Kingdom of Days: April 20
jetpack-related-posts.author: Ken
jetpack-related-posts.excerpt: The live debut of "I Wanna Be With You" and the first public Seeger Sessions warm-up show lead the highlights from this date in Bruce history.

jetpack-related-posts.title: Kingdom of Days: March 13
jetpack-related-posts.author: Ken
jetpack-related-posts.excerpt: Take in highlights from Springsteen shows in every decade today.

jetpack-related-posts.title: Kingdom of Days: March 19
jetpack-related-posts.author: Ken
jetpack-related-posts.excerpt: Bruce makes a Daily Show appearance, records tracks for the Seeger Sessions album, and closes out the L.A. Sports Arena on this date in history. Highlights and more inside.
